--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:

> OK but as I said in an earlier email, if the evolution stops 
progressing 
> because the problem is too hard, or all of the species are bogged 
down 
> in local maxima, then the simple species will become gradually 
reduced 
> and bloat will set in. Protection of simple structure is only 
assured 
> while evolution is progressing, I think that is where the source 
of our 
> disharmony lies. :)
> 

Actually I think it's more complicated than this.  There are two 
cases: 1) Where the compatibility threshold is fixed, and 2) Where 
the compatibility threshold is dynamically adjusting to attain a 
goal # of species.

In case 1, if no species are improving, then more and more species
will be created as topology is added, and all the species will be
shrinking in size.  After a large numberof generations, species will 
begin to be so small that some species simply will not get a chance 
to reproduce by chance.  However, note that there is no particular 
bias in this probability of extinction towards species of smaller 
topologies.  In fact, for any particular species, it is unlikely it 
will go extinct.  Thus, on average, you would expect the simple 
species to persist.  Over an extremely long timescale, you would 
expect to lose the simplest species a few times, but this bottom-
level complexity would increase extremely slowly over an enormous 
timescale.  This is not what is generally considered bloat.  In 
fact, in the hypothesized situation where everything is stagnant, it 
cannot be said whether adding topology is "functional" 
or "nonfunctional" since we don't know why no one can solve the 
problem.  Thus it is probably *correct* to very slowly abandon the 
simplest topologies after hundreds of generations of no progress.

In case 2, if no specie are improving, once the target # of species 
is obtained, new topology will tend to get added within each 
species, because there is no room to create new species.  But 
remember many times adding topology decreases fitness.  And by our 
hypothesis, it does not increase fitness.  Thus, the majority of 
added topology will not be selected as parents, since they are 
inferior to their simpler counterparts in the same species. So you 
will see a churn inside all the species where most of the new 
topology innovations get thrown out.  Once in a while, new topology 
may have no effect on performance.  Such topology then has a 
probability of getting reproduced.  So you would see again a very 
slow increase in complexity in all the species.  But again, this 
makes sense, since you are by hypothesis completely stuck, and it 
wouldn't make sense to stay in the simplest spaces forever.

Overall, the point is, the "bloat" in a stagnating population is 
really just appropriate incrementation of the search space after 
very long periods of time.  It is not clear there is any reasonable 
alternative.  For instance, if you were searching for lost money in 
your living room for 5 hours, wouldn't eventually add some new rooms 
to your search?  It wouldn't make sense to keep the search only in 
one room just for the sake of simplicity.
